elements.title: Acquisitions and Regulatory Framework

data.value: The BHC Act permits acquisitions of banks by bank holding companies, subject to deposit-percentage, age of bank charter requirements and other restrictions. It mandates that a bank holding company obtain prior approval from the Federal Reserve before acquiring more than 5% voting shares, taking actions that result in a bank becoming a subsidiary, or merging with another bank holding company. The Federal Reserve will not approve transactions that would create monopolistic conditions or restrain trade.

Federal law, under the Change in Bank Control Act, restricts the amount of voting stock that can be acquired without prior regulatory approval. Advance notice is required if control (including acquiring 10% or more of outstanding common stock) is to be taken, which creates a rebuttable presumption of control.

The company is required to comply with various corporate governance and financial reporting requirements under the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, SEC rules, PCAOB, and Nasdaq requirements, including management and independent auditor reports on internal controls as part of the Annual Report on Form 10-K.

Section 13 of the BHC Act, known as the Volcker Rule, generally prohibits banking organizations from engaging in specific proprietary trading activities and limits their ownership in or sponsorship of covered funds, with exceptions for organizations meeting certain asset thresholds.

elements.title: CORPORATE GOVERNANCE - Board Leadership Structure

data.value: The Company policy does not mandate the separation of the roles of CEO/President and Chairman of the Board. Instead, the decision on whether to separate these roles is reviewed regularly based on the company's position and board composition.

The Board has determined that having the President and CEO, Mr. Mills, also serve as Chairman of the Board is in the best interests of the stockholders, leveraging his extensive knowledge of the organization and industry.
James D’Agostino, Jr. has been elected to serve as the Lead Independent Director, ensuring independent oversight and effective communication between the Chairman and independent directors.

Includes presiding over board meetings in the absence of the Chairman, setting meeting agendas, facilitating executive sessions, acting as a liaison with regulators, and ensuring robust communication among independent directors.

elements.title: CORPORATE GOVERNANCE

elements.title: CORPORATE GOVERNANCE Director Nominees

data.value: Nominations for election to the Board may be made by the Board or by any stockholder entitled to vote at the Annual Meeting, in accordance with the Company's Bylaws.

The Nominating and Corporate Governance Committee is responsible for identifying and recommending candidates to the Board as vacancies occur and ensuring the Board has a proper mix of skills and experience.

Director candidates are evaluated based on familiarity with the financial services industry, personal financial stability, willingness to serve, adherence to Corporate Governance Principles, ethics, integrity, and commitment to representing stockholders' long-term interests.

While there is no separate diversity policy, the Committee considers diversity in terms of knowledge, experience, skills, and background, aiming to reflect the diversity of customers, stockholders, and communities.

Transactions by Origin Bank or the Company with related parties are governed by formal policies and regulatory requirements (including Sections 23A and 23B of the Federal Reserve Act and Regulation O), with guidance provided in the Ethics Policy.
Currently, the Board does not engage any third parties to identify or evaluate potential director candidates.

The Compensation Committee meets at least quarterly, develops agendas in consultation with the Chair and Chief Human Resources Officer, holds executive sessions, and may invite management, employees, or outside advisors.

The CEO, along with the Bank’s President and CEO and the Chief Human Resources Officer, interface with the Committee to discuss executive compensation, though the CEO does not participate in deliberations about his/her own compensation.

The Committee may form subcommittees and delegate authority, and it has the power to select, retain, and approve fees and terms of external advisors, including compensation consultants, considering Nasdaq independence factors.

elements.title: COMPENSATION DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS / Executive Compensation Governance Practices

data.value: The document emphasizes the importance of attracting and retaining highly qualified and loyal employees, including the executive team, by offering competitive compensation programs that reward high performance and contribute to long-term shareholder value.

Compensation programs are designed to be competitive, encourage behaviors that align with strategic organizational goals, and foster a work culture based on respect, integrity, teamwork, inclusion, equity, initiative, and individual growth.

The document highlights best practices such as tying executive compensation to both short-term and long-term company performance, engaging independent compensation consultants, conducting annual risk reviews, maintaining clawback policies, and requiring meaningful stock ownership from executives and directors.

The provided table divides practices into 'What We Do' and 'What We Don't Do'. 'What We Do' includes linking substantial executive compensation to performance goals, risk management practices, and vesting structures. 'What We Don't Do' prohibits practices such as 'excise tax gross-ups', repricing stock options without stockholder approval, hedging of company stock, excessive perquisites, and premature dividend payments.

elements.title: COMPENSATION DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS

data.value: The Compensation Committee assessed Meridian’s independence in accordance with SEC rules and Nasdaq listing standards, ensuring that the services provided did not present any conflict of interest.

The CEO conducts an annual performance review of executive officers and provides recommendations to the Compensation Committee on their compensation. The CEO also participates in the Committee’s deliberations regarding compensation for other executives.

The Compensation Committee meets annually in executive session with the CEO to discuss his compensation and performance based on his annual incentive plan objectives. The final incentive payout recommendation for the CEO is approved and then presented to the Board for review.

The Compensation Peer Group is updated annually using competitive market data, input from compensation consultants, and management feedback. Factors include asset size, industry, and geographic region.

The approved peer group for 2022 comprises 19 companies with a median asset size of approximately $11.3 billion, including companies such as ServisFirst Bancshares, Inc., Southside Bancshares Inc., Stock Yards Bancorp, Inc., and others.

elements.title: COMPENSATION DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS / LTI Plan

data.value: The bonus compensation table provides performance-based bonus details for six executive officers. Notably, all executives share the same Financial Factor (126.9%), but differ in Individual Scorecard ratings. Drake Mills, CEO, received the highest bonus of $554,481 with a 150% score, while William Wallace, IV, CFO, received the lowest bonus of $95,145. Combined performance metrics range from 119.7% to 132.7%.

The LTI (Long-Term Incentive) plan redesign introduces a mix of performance-based and time-based equity awards. In 2022, executives received equal value allocations of Performance Stock Units (PSUs) and Restricted Stock Units (RSUs). The table details target values in dollars and share allocations for each executive, with Drake Mills, CEO, having the highest target value of $104,475 (2,847 shares for both PSU and RSU).
The re-designed LTI strategy aims to better align executive performance with shareholder interests and includes multi-year vesting provisions for retention.

elements.title: COMPENSATION DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS

data.value: In 2022, the Compensation Committee approved the grant of performance stock units (PSUs) to each NEO hired prior to the grant date. The PSUs are linked to achieving ROAA and ROAE targets over a three-year period ending December 31, 2024, with payout levels ranging from 50% to 150% based on a threshold-target-maximum structure. A table titled 'Performance Metrics and Payout Structure' outlines these metrics, though it does not include specific metric data.

In 2022, RSUs were granted to each NEO and vest ratably over a three-year period, subject to continuous employment. Unvested RSUs are forfeited if employment is not maintained through each vesting date. Shares of common stock are issued upon vesting.

On December 7, 2022, the Compensation Committee and independent Board members approved a special one-time stock award for the CEO, consisting of 129,736 RSUs and 129,735 PSUs with an aggregate value of $10 million. The award became effective on December 13, 2022, and is contingent upon a 2-year non-competition covenant along with standard non-solicitation provisions.
Payouts for PSUs are interpolated on a straight-line basis between the threshold (50% payout), target (100% payout), and maximum (150% payout) performance levels.

elements.title: COMPENSATION DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS

data.value: The CEO RSUs vest in five approximately equal installments on the third, fourth, fifth, sixth, and seventh anniversaries of the Grant Date, subject to continued employment or provided earlier upon death, disability, termination without cause, or resignation for good reason. In the event of a CIC where the surviving Company does not assume or substitute equivalent equity awards, the awards become fully vested.

The PSUs are eligible to vest based on achievement of five pre-established Stock Price Hurdles during a seven-year performance period ending on December 31, 2029. Each hurdle represents a 20% price appreciation over the 20-day average closing price at the Grant Date and must be maintained for 20 consecutive trading days. Vesting occurs on the later of the achievement of the hurdle or the respective anniversary, subject to continued employment.

The Company has established Supplemental Executive Retirement Plans (SERPs) available to select senior executives (NEOs), including Mr. Mills, Mr. Hall, and Mr. Brolly. These are unfunded, nonqualified deferred compensation retirement plans designed in compliance with Section 409A.

An Executive Supplemental Income Agreement (ESIA) with Mr. Hall provides additional income benefits as a defined benefit style program, with benefits paid in equal annual installments and tied to years of service.

The Origin Bank Nonqualified Deferred Compensation Plan, approved on December 7, 2022 and effective January 1, 2023, allows employees including NEOs to make deferral elections with respect to base salary, bonus, or stock units.

elements.title: COMPENSATION DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS

data.value: The Company currently does not make discretionary contributions to the DCP. Any potential contributions would be subject to a 5-year ratable vesting schedule with acceleration in cases such as a CIC event, participant's death, disability, or retirement.

Participants make individual investment elections for their cash deferral amounts under the DCP, with cash deferrals being fully invested in the selected investment options and 100% vested except for any company contributions.
Participants can elect to receive in-service or separation distributions either as a lump sum or in substantially equal annual installments over 5 or 10 years, respectively.

NEOs receive limited perquisites including the use of company cars or car allowances, payment of life insurance premiums, reimbursement for country club dues, and other competitive expenses. Additionally, standard employee benefit plans (health, dental, vision, group life, and disability insurance) are provided.

The Company offers a 401(k) plan with an employer match of 50 cents on every dollar contributed up to 6% of eligible compensation, and an Employee Stock Purchase Plan (ESPP) that allows purchase of shares at a 15 percent discount.

NEOs are entitled to limited CIC and severance protections, which are designed to enable key executives to act in the best interest of the Company without undue personal risk and to foster management stability during uncertain periods.

The Compensation Committee oversees executive compensation policies, aligning pay with performance and conducting annual risk assessments through the Chief Risk Officer to evaluate the design and operation of incentive programs.

elements.title: COMPENSATION DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS

data.value: The document explains that incentive-based compensation for NEOs is subject to clawback if the company must file an accounting restatement and the Board determines that a fraudulent or intentional act or omission contributed to the need for the restatement.

The policy restricts Covered Persons from engaging in hedging, pledging, or holding company securities in margin accounts. It outlines rules for hedging transactions, limitations on margin accounts, and conditions for pledging securities as collateral.

If Mr. Brolly voluntarily terminates, is involuntarily terminated without Cause or for Good Reason, or becomes disabled, he receives the vested benefit of the Accrued Liability Retirement Balance as of termination, paid as a lump sum within 30 days.

If he dies while employed or before retirement, his beneficiary receives the Accrued Liability Retirement Balance in a lump sum.

If Mr. Hall is terminated without Cause or resigns prior to age 65, he receives severance compensation in 15 annual installments equal to the accrued balance with interest. Under a CIC, if terminated (except for Cause), he receives the annual benefit as if retired at 65. For termination for Cause at any time, he forfeits all benefits.

Effective October 29, 2019. If he dies before 60, no benefit; if terminated involuntarily without Cause or for Good Reason, or becomes disabled, he receives 100% of the Accrued Liability Retirement Balance. data.value: Mr. McGee does not have a traditional employment agreement but entered into a CIC Agreement with the Bank on February 22, 2022. The agreement has an initial term of three years and renews automatically for successive one-year terms unless notice is provided 90 days before a term ends. If terminated within two years after a CIC, or under conditions defined as the earlier of the commencement of CIC negotiations or six months prior to a CIC (except for Cause or Good Reason), he is entitled to severance benefits. These benefits include a lump sum cash payment equal to two times his then-current base salary and a lump sum cash payment equal to two times the average STIP bonus paid over the three calendar years (or fewer if he has been employed for a shorter period). The CIC benefits are to be paid no later than the 60th day after the later of his termination and the Closing Date. Additionally, post-CIC restrictions include a one-year period during which he may not solicit the Company's customers, and a prohibition against recruiting or hiring recent employees.

Mr. Moore entered into a CIC Agreement with the Company effective March 28, 2018. After an initial term ending on March 27, 2021, the agreement automatically renews for successive one-year terms unless notice is given 90 days prior to the term's conclusion. If he is terminated within two years following a CIC, or under specified conditions (the earlier of the commencement of CIC negotiations or six months prior to a CIC, excluding terminations for Cause or Good Reason), he is entitled to severance benefits that include a lump sum cash payment of two times his current base salary, a lump sum cash payment of two times his average STIP bonus over the previous three calendar years, and any equity-type award that becomes fully vested and exercisable. These benefits are to be paid no later than the 30th day after the later of the termination of service or the effective date of a CIC. Additionally, there is a nine-month post-CIC restriction on soliciting existing customers and a six-month restriction on recruiting or hiring recent employees.

elements.title: EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION TABLES

data.value: For 2022, the median employee was identified using a population of 907 employees as of December 31, 2022, which included full-time, part-time, temporary, and seasonal employees. The identification excluded 115 employees from BTH Bank acquired in a transaction that closed on August 1, 2022.

The median of annual total compensation was determined using payroll records as reported on IRS Form W-2 for fiscal year 2022. Annualization of compensation was applied to full-time and part-time permanent employees, without making full-time equivalent adjustments for part-time employees. Employees were ranked by total cash compensation (excluding the PEO) to identify the median employee.

The median employee's total annual compensation was calculated by aggregating wages, cash incentives, equity incentives, Employee 401(k) employer contributions, and any applicable perquisites earned or paid in 2022, following the same methodology as the PEO's total annual compensation from the Summary Compensation Table.

The PEO's annual total compensation was taken from the ‘Total’ column of the 2022 Summary Compensation Table. During 2022, the PEO received stock awards with an aggregate grant date fair value of $8.6 million, of which $8.2 million were one-time awards associated with aligning the PEO’s pay with the Company’s performance under the LTIP.

Excluding the one-time stock awards, the PEO’s annual compensation would have been $2.0 million. This gives a compensation ratio of approximately 1:30 between the PEO and the median employee on a normalized basis, reflecting the Company's compensation philosophy.

elements.title: EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION TABLES – Pay Versus Performance ("PVP")

data.value: The table presents executive compensation and related performance metrics for the years ended December 31, 2022, 2021, and 2020. It links the compensation actually paid to the CEO and non-CEO NEOs with key financial performance measures.
CEO compensation increased significantly from approximately $1.56M (2020) to over $10.22M (2022). Non-CEO NEOs received average compensation of about $0.67M-$1.17M over the period.

Key metrics include Total Shareholder Return (TSR) for OBNK and its peer group, net income, and ROAA. Notable trends: net income rose from $36,000 in 2020 to $108.5M in 2021 then declined to $87.7M in 2022; ROAA peaked at 1.45% in 2021 before declining to 1.01% in 2022.

Drake Mills served as CEO & President for all three years. Other Named Executive Officers varied by year: 2022 - William Wallace, IV, M. Lance Hall, Stephen Brolly, Derek McGee, Preston Moore; 2021 - Stephen Brolly, M. Lance Hall, Jim Crotwell, Preston Moore; 2020 - Stephen Brolly, M. Lance Hall, Cary Davis, Preston Moore.

Cumulative TSR is reported for an initial $100 investment as of December 31, 2019. For OBNK, TSR was -25.47% (2020), 56.45% (2021), and -13.30% (2022) leading to a cumulative three-year TSR of 1.09%, with the 2022 value of $101.09.

elements.title: Interest Rate Sensitivity and Its Impact on Financial Performance

data.value: Earnings and financial condition are highly dependent on net interest income, defined as the difference between interest earned on assets and interest paid on liabilities.

Changes in market interest rates can cause fluctuations in net interest income. For instance, simulations as of December 31, 2022 projected that a 100 basis point increase would boost net interest income by 3.64% and a 200 basis point increase by 7.10%, while a 100 basis point decrease would reduce it by 2.26% and a 200 basis point decrease by 6.72%.
Interest rates are influenced by factors such as inflation, economic conditions, Federal monetary policies, and the stability of domestic and foreign markets.

The impact on net interest income depends on the differential repricing of interest-earning assets versus interest-bearing liabilities. Assets or liabilities maturing/repricing at different speeds can either mitigate or exacerbate the effect of interest rate changes.

data.key: Impact on Investment Securities and Other Financial Metrics
data.value: Higher interest rates can reduce the market value of investment securities available for sale, impacting other comprehensive income, while changes may also affect loan origination volume, collateral values, and liquidity.

The document mentions a mortgage servicing rights portfolio with unpaid principal balances of $1.90 billion and details the sale of part of the GNMA portfolio, which impacted related assets and liabilities.

Although practices have been implemented to reduce interest rate risk, there is no guarantee that these measures will always be successful, leaving the institution exposed to potential adverse effects on overall profitability.

data.value: The section presents a consolidated discussion of financial condition and results of operations, primarily at the bank level through the wholly-owned subsidiary, Origin Bank. It covers historical performance and forward-looking statements.

The discussion includes forward-looking statements that involve risks, uncertainties, and assumptions which could lead to materially different outcomes from management's expectations. It references cautionary sections on forward-looking statements and risk factors.

The discussion emphasizes key accounting policies and estimates prepared in accordance with U.S. GAAP, including the evaluation of significant accounting estimates that are subject to judgment and revision.

Details on the methodology for calculating expected credit losses, based on historical experience, current conditions, and forecasts, are provided. Components such as charge-offs, recoveries, and provisions are discussed as factors affecting the allowance.
The report includes year-over-year comparisons between 2022 and 2021, with references to prior periods for additional context.

elements.title: Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements

data.value: Origin Bancorp, Inc. is a financial holding company headquartered in Ruston, Louisiana. The Company's wholly-owned bank subsidiary, Origin Bank, operates 59 banking centers and offers a broad range of financial services.

The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Origin Bancorp, Inc. and all entities in which it has a controlling financial interest. All significant intercompany balances and transactions have been eliminated.
The Company's accounting and financial reporting policies conform to U.S. GAAP.
The Bank is the only significant subsidiary managed as a community banking segment.
Management makes estimates and assumptions that impact the financial statements. Actual results could differ from those estimates.

data.value: The Company recognizes gain or loss on the sale of other assets and OREO when control of the property transfers to the buyer with a fixed transaction price and occasional financing of a portion of the purchase price.

This revenue includes mortgage production, sales, and servicing revenues, such as fees and income, gains and losses on sales, and changes in fair value of mortgage loans and MSRs, along with risk management activities related to the mortgage pipeline.

Income tax expense is calculated as the sum of current tax and changes in deferred taxes, with a discussion on valuation allowances, tax positions, and recognition criteria for uncertain income tax positions.
The cost of employee services for stock options, restricted stock, and performance stock awards is measured at fair value on the grant date and recognized over the service period.

Investments in limited partnerships, LLCs, and other privately held companies are accounted for either by the equity method or at amortized cost, with impairment assessments based on the investee's cash generation capability and subjective factors.

elements.title: Notes on Investments in Tax Credit Entities and Earnings Per Share

data.value: ORIGIN BANCORP, INC.

The Company invests in tax credit-motivated projects, particularly those associated with Low-Income Housing Tax Credits. These investments are recorded as an offset to income tax provision and are amortized over the compliance period.
Amortization of the investment begins at the issuance of the certificate of occupancy and is spread over 15 years for Low-Income Housing Tax Credit programs.
There is a risk of credit recapture if the project fails to maintain compliance during the compliance period; however, no such events have occurred to date.
Investments in tax credit entities were $9.4 million at December 31, 2022 and $11.1 million at December 31, 2021.
Basic and diluted earnings per share are computed using the treasury method, considering potential shares from stock options, restricted stock awards, and other dilutive instruments.
References to ASU No. 2019-12 (Income Taxes) and ASU No. 2021-06 (Presentation of Financial Statements) indicate recent changes in accounting for income taxes and financial statement disclosures.

elements.title: Note 10 - Mortgage Banking

data.value: The table 'Mortgage Banking Revenue Overview' presents revenue figures from mortgage banking operations for 2020-2022, including categories such as Gain (loss) on sale of loans held for sale, Originations of MSRs, Servicing, Total gross mortgage revenue, MSR valuation adjustments, Mortgage HFS and pipeline fair value adjustment, MSR hedge impact, and Mortgage banking revenue (loss). The data shows a significant declining trend in revenue over the three-year period.

The 'Servicing Rights Balance and Adjustments' table shows changes in the balance of mortgage servicing rights from 2020 to 2022. It includes details such as the beginning balance, additions from servicing acquisitions and organic additions, valuation adjustments, and the ending balance. The trend indicates a recovery and growth in servicing rights value from previous negative adjustments.

During the second half of 2022, the Company recognized an impairment of $2.0 million and entered an agreement to sell its GNMA MSR portfolio. Approximately $1.8 million in GNMA MSR was sold with no significant additional gain or loss, and related repurchase asset and offsetting liability of $24.6 million were derecognized in Q1 2023.
The Company receives annual servicing fee income approximating 0.28% of the outstanding balance of the underlying loans.

The Company is exposed to potential losses due to mortgage loan servicing putback expenses. As of December 31, 2022, the reserve for putback expenses was $217,000, down from $379,000 in 2021. There is inherent uncertainty in estimating future putback expenses based on various factors.

Additional Note on Net Operating Loss Carryforwards
data.value: At December 31, 2022, the Company had $126.5 million of Federal gross net operating loss carryforwards and $22.8 million in gross state net operating losses carryforwards. Of these, $3.1 million in Federal net operating loss carryforwards acquired in previous business combinations are expiring between 2023 and 2028, and 65.4% of the state losses can be carried forward indefinitely with the remainder expiring between 2028 and 2042. A valuation allowance of $899k has been established for the expected unused losses.

elements.title: Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm To the Shareholders, Board of Directors and Audit Committee Origin Bancorp, Inc.

data.key: Opinion on Internal Control over Financial Reporting
data.value: In our opinion, the Company maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2022, based on criteria established in Internal Control – Integrated Framework (2013) issued by COSO.
We audited the consolidated financial statements for December 31, 2022 and 2021 and for the three-year period ended December 31, 2022, expressing an unqualified opinion.
Conducted in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB).
FORVIS, LLP (Formerly BKD, LLP) from Little Rock, Arkansas.

elements.title: Regulatory Capital Requirements and Dividend Distribution Restrictions

data.value: The FDICIA requires prompt corrective action for depository institutions that do not meet minimum capital requirements, establishing five regulatory capital tiers.
Well capitalized, adequately capitalized, undercapitalized, significantly undercapitalized, and critically undercapitalized based on various capital measures.
Depository institutions are generally prohibited from making capital distributions, including paying dividends, if they become undercapitalized.
Undercapitalized institutions face restrictions on borrowing, accepting brokered deposits (without a waiver), growth limitations, and the need for capital restoration plans.

Origin Bank must maintain minimum ratios: 6.5% CET1, 8.0% Tier 1, 10.0% total capital to risk-weighted assets, and a 5.0% leverage ratio. Bank holding companies must meet additional Federal Reserve standards.
Under state law and federal regulatory capital requirements, dividend payments are subject to restrictions ensuring that capital adequacy is maintained post-distribution.
In 2022, the Company and Origin Bank exceeded the applicable well-capitalized standards and met the capital conservation buffer, with expectations to continue in 2023.

elements.title: Market Risk & Interest Rate Sensitivity Disclosure

data.value: Quantitative and qualitative disclosures regarding market risk focus on interest rate volatility and its impact on income, expenses, and the fair market value of interest-bearing assets and liabilities.
Interest rate risk is defined as the potential for economic losses due to changes in interest rates, affecting net interest income and fair market values.

The Bank manages interest rate risk through its Asset-Liability Management Committee, the use of derivatives such as interest rate swaps in limited circumstances, and interest rate shock simulation models.
Strategies include structuring consolidated balance sheets appropriately, monitoring interest rate sensitivity, and regular review of asset and liability sensitivities.

Words such as 'anticipates', 'believes', 'estimates', 'expects', 'foresees', 'intends', 'plans', 'projects' and verbs like 'could', 'may', 'might', 'should', 'will', 'would' signal forward-looking statements.

Economic uncertainty, deteriorating economic conditions, volatile interest rates, fluctuating capital markets, impact of inflation, changes in interest rate margin, variability in loan-related metrics (prepayment speeds, loan origination, charge-offs, loan loss provisions), global economic conditions, supply-chain disruptions, labor pressures, increased unemployment, credit risks related to commercial real estate and loans, natural disasters, cybersecurity threats, and the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic and related governmental measures including the CARES Act.

elements.title: Transactions with Affiliates, FDIC Insurance Assessments, and Safety & Soundness Standards

data.value: Transactions with Origin Bank and the Company or nonbank affiliates are generally limited to 10% of Origin Bank’s capital and surplus individually, and 20% in aggregate.
Loans and other credit extensions from Origin Bank to the Company or affiliates are typically required to be secured by eligible collateral in specified amounts.

Deposits are insured by the FDIC’s DIF up to $250,000 per depositor, per insured bank, for each account ownership category.

FDIC calculates quarterly deposit insurance assessments based on an institution’s average total consolidated assets less its average tangible equity, with additional factors for institutions over $10 billion in assets.

data.key: DIF Reserve Ratio and Restoration Plan
data.value: As of June 30, 2020, the DIF reserve ratio was 1.30%, below the statutory minimum of 1.35%. A restoration plan was established (initially on September 15, 2020 and amended on October 18, 2022) to restore the ratio by September 30, 2028, including an increase in the base assessment rate by 2 basis points starting in 2023.

data.value: Loans are classified into five categories: pass, special mention, substandard, doubtful, and loss.

Substandard loans exhibit weaknesses jeopardizing orderly liquidation of debt.
Doubtful loans have weaknesses that make full collection questionable.
Loss loans are charged off with low recovery expectations.

elements.title: Credit Risk and Loan Portfolio Analysis

data.value: Loans are classified as nonperforming when full principal and accrued interest are unlikely to be collected or when they are 90 days past due. They remain nonperforming until performance improves to a level that full collection is reasonably expected.
A charge-off is taken in the period when the loss on a loan is confirmed, based on historical charge-off experience and loss given default methodology derived from an internal risk rating process.

Allocations for each major loan category are established based on historical data, internal risk ratings, and adjustments for trends, changes in loan mix, delinquencies, and prior losses. External and internal influences not reflected in historical loss data are also considered.

data.key: Risk Elements Considered by Loan Type
data.value: For commercial real estate: debt service coverage ratio, operating results of the owner, loan-to-value ratio, collateral age/condition, and volatility of income/property values. For construction/land loans: project feasibility, presale/prelease contract quality, developer experience, and loan-to-value ratio. For residential mortgages: borrower's repayment ability, debt-to-income ratio, employment/income stability, loan-to-value ratio, and collateral marketability. For commercial and industrial loans: debt service coverage ratio, operating results, borrower’s business and financial expertise, and collateral quality.

The BTH merger impacted the 2022 loan portfolio with a provision of $23.9 million, classified loans of $17.8 million, past due loans of $6.0 million, and nonperforming LHFI of $2.6 million. Additionally, the allowance for loan credit losses increased significantly, driven by a decrease in nonperforming LHFI and an increase in the credit loss allowance.

elements.title: Loan Risk Rating Classifications

data.value: Loans within this risk rating are further categorized as follows:
Well-collateralized by cash equivalent instruments held by the Banks.

Borrowers with excellent asset quality and liquidity. Borrowers' capitalization and liquidity exceed industry norms. Borrowers in this category have significant levels of liquid assets and have a low level of leverage.

Borrowers with strong financial strength and excellent liquidity that consistently demonstrate strong operating performance. Borrowers in this category generally have a sizable net worth that can be converted into liquid assets within 12 months.

Borrowers with sound credit quality and financial performance, including liquidity. Borrowers are supported by sufficient cash flow coverage generated through operations across the full business cycle.

Loans generally meet minimum requirements for an acceptable loan in accordance with lending policy, but possess one or more attributes that cause the overall risk profile to be higher than the majority of newly approved loans.

A passing loan with one or more factors that identify a potential weakness in the overall ability of the borrower to repay the loan. These weaknesses are generally mitigated by other factors that reduce the risk of delinquency or loss.
This grade is intended to be temporary and includes borrowers whose credit quality has deteriorated and is at risk of further decline.

This grade includes "Substandard" loans under regulatory guidelines. Substandard loans exhibit a well-defined weakness that jeopardizes debt repayment in accordance with contractual agreements, even though the loan may be performing. These obligations are characterized by the distinct possibility that a loss may be incurred if these weaknesses are not corrected and repayment may be dependent upon collateral liquidation or secondary source of repayment.

This grade includes "Doubtful" loans under regulatory guidelines. Such loans are placed on nonaccrual status and repayment may be dependent upon collateral with no readily determinable valuation or valuations that are highly subjective in nature. Repayment for these loans is considered improbable based on currently existing facts and circumstances.
This grade includes "Loss" loans under regulatory guidelines. Loss loans are charged-off or written down when repayment is not expected.

This table presents a comprehensive loan risk rating system ranging from 1 (minimal risk) to 0 (loss). The system categorizes loans into different risk levels, with ratings 1-6 considered 'Pass' grades. The classifications become progressively more severe from Special Mention (7) through Loss (0). Each rating is accompanied by detailed criteria and characteristics that define the borrower's credit quality, financial strength, and likelihood of repayment. The system appears to be aligned with regulatory guidelines and serves as a framework for loan portfolio management and risk assessment.
